results.title: No myth
results.creator_credit: Open Channel Productions and Claire Jager
results.brief_description: This video exposes the entrenched attitudes and myths surrounding Australia’s most hidden crime: domestic violence. “No Myth” was produced to explain why secrecy, shame and misplaced guilt accompanies domestic violence, and why women who experience it are frequently too scared, ashamed and isolated to confide in anyone.
results.description: This video exposes the entrenched attitudes and myths surrounding Australia’s most hidden crime: domestic violence. “No Myth” was produced to explain why secrecy, shame and misplaced guilt accompanies domestic violence, and why women who experience it are frequently too scared, ashamed and isolated to confide in anyone.

results.title: Life in the Desert
results.brief_description: The viewer is taken into the Australian desert and shown the amazing variety of plants and animals and informed how they manage to survive in such extreme conditions.

results.title: The Long Now
results.brief_description: There is a giant clock ringing deep inside a mountain in the belly of the Sierra Diablo Ranges - The land of the Devil. It is a huge clock, hundreds of feet tall, designed to tick for 10,000 years. The mountain in which the clock resides is privately owned by Jeff Bezos. Programmed never to chime the same melody twice, its anyone’s guess how many beautiful songs will never be heard over the clock’s 10 millennial lifespan. Xanthe Dobbie’s new experimental desktop performance ponders the human urge to seek immortality. Featuring original epic hero Gilgamesh and the disembodied deep fake voice of Alan Rickman, The Long Now collapses histories, illuminating ancient and contemporary myth-making practices.

results.title: Cold comfort: Australia's nuclear responsibilities
results.creator_credit: Open Channel Productions and Jack White
results.brief_description: Cold Comfort is a lively and incisive documentary on the local and global consequences of the decision to export Australian uranium. It presents statements by those who support the mining of uranium for nuclear energy purposes, alongside those who oppose it. The program incorporates archival footage, and contemporary interviews to chart Australia’s participation in atomic history. Presented in four sequences. “The Uranium debate”, “The History of the bomb”, “Transportation of radioactive waste” and “Fallout from Chernobyl and Three Mile Island”.

results.title: Banjo's Australia
results.brief_description: This program explains A. B. Paterson’s contribution and significance to Australian literature from the 1890’s to the World War I. It traces Paterson’s personal history, his love of the bush, his admiration for camaraderie and spirit of the bush and the pathos and humour of bush life.

results.title: Beautiful lies: a film about Peter Carey
results.creator_credit: Australia Council, Australian Film Commission and Don Featherstone
results.brief_description: Peter Carey is one of Australia’s most talented writers. All four of his published works have won major literary awards. This film, takes a journey through his life and work and looks at the way he transforms his native country into a bizarre land of nightmares and surreal comedy. Throughout the film, an interview with Peter Carey is interwoven with lavish dramatisation. An intriguing and illuminating film about a remarkable writer.

results.title: Patterns
results.brief_description: Patterns is a documentary which explores issues to do with politics, work, art and women’s history. A number of threads are woven between the sweatshop and the art gallery, the glory box and the political banner, bourgeois femininity and the question: should a feminist knit? An incisive and kaleidoscopic exploration of needlework and its place in women’s lives.

results.title: Time changes
results.brief_description: “Time changes” is an experimental, self-reflexive film, comprised of footage filmed over four years by Sue Ford and her friends. Described by the artist as being “a documentary about time and change, focusing on four men who were filmmakers and close friends”, the film features friends Stuart Green, Chris Maudson, John Phillips and Paul Reed, as well as Ford, her children Emma and Ben, and artists Richard Brennan, Bonita Ely, Margo Nash and Ashe Venn. Through unscripted dialogue, the friends’ conversations range across topics such as the integrity of filmmaking and creative practice to ways of living and relationships.

results.title: The Goal
results.brief_description: Meet Bella, a soccer obsessed ten year old. She eats, breathes and dreams soccer. There’s just one problem. She would rather eat junk food while watching a match on TV than actually play the game herself. When a freak accident occurs, everyone mistakes her for a soccer superstar. However, due to her lack of soccer skills she fails miserably. Will she change her attitude towards exercise or remain a couch potato forever?

results.title: Angelica Mesiti: The Calling interview
results.creator_credit: Jesse Taylorsmith, Shelley Matulick, Kim Montgomery, ACMI and Ian Potter Cultural Trust
results.brief_description:
In this interview (filmed as part of activities associated with the ACMI Exhibition ‘Angelica Mesiti: The Calling’) the artist reflects on the structure, approach and the processes involved in creating the work.

‘The Calling’ is a three channel video installation that focuses on whistling languages, ancient forms of non-verbal communication which are still used in 2013 to communicate in isolated and difficult landscapes.

To conduct research for ‘The Calling’, artist Angelica Mesiti travelled to the village of Kuskoy in Northern Turkey, the island of La Gomera in The Canary Islands and the Island of Evia in Greece where whistling languages are still in use.
